Happy #InternationalWomensDay where our notifications go up but our pay does not.
Celebrate us by giving us @PayEquityNow

With equal pay, we can afford to live in places that recognize our body autonomy, health care needs, & reproductive rights.

Our rights begin in our wallets.
Late stage Crapitalism

When capitalism practiced greedily creates a culture of always-on-even-on-â€œvacationâ€ corporate cultism, no amount of paid PTO or unlimited PTO is going to give you back your life.
Our work culture is STRICT about our 3 day weekends to defend against reinfection with corp cultism.

@thatglitchth0 Sometimes we hire people.
https://t.co/M8n1ghInzK

Itâ€™s a leadership choice & I defend it so much because *I* deserve my 3 day weekends too. I make sure itâ€™s very clear that non emergency messages during PTO is not only not ok, but do it & face my â€œthis isnâ€™t how we show respect to colleaguesâ€ message followed by email shutdown.

Weâ€™re unfortunately not in a world that values life above work cultism, so we must find or create pockets we protect.
My company is one such peaceful pocket protector.
Find or create yours.
Unlimited PTO or not, it comes down to culture & respecting rest that makes the difference
@FrankMcG @sherrod_im The unlimited PTO is in addition to the 79 guaranteed days of PTO, I should be clear.

Youâ€™ve heard of 0-day

And maybe n-day

Meet p-day (patch-day)

Multiparty vulnerability disclosure in libraries is extremely tricky business, especially when timezones are involved.

Patch diff in 1 distro let CVE-2023-38545 out of the bag faster than your vendors can spell SBOM

What appears to have happened:

- Well-intentioned announcement about a pending patch in a popular package meant to give vendors time to roll patches & teams time to inventory assets & dependencies

- Vuln coordination of patch release went off by 1 day early in 1 vendor

- Oops

Vulnerability Disclosure:

So simple to understand & explain that nobody likes to hear it when they donâ€™t understand the crux of it & are oversimplifying it to the point of explaining it incorrectly

Also Vuln Disclosure:

My area of expertise lots of people like to explain to me

Cool: centralized reporting of vulnerabilities affecting USgov agencies
Not cool: opt-in for agencies so not actually centralized
Cool: free triage
Not cool: triage isnâ€™t the hard part to get right in Vuln Disclosure & is context-sensitive
MIA: vuln handling processes to fix bugs

Vuln Disclosure Policies as receivers (not researchers) are just the published way to receive bug reports & notes about how you as bug receiver will handle those reports as part of Vuln Disclosure PROGRAMS that should be built on a foundation of Vulnerability Handling Processes.

Vuln Disclosure & vuln Handling processes are defined in ISO 29147 & 30111.

Iâ€™m one of the principal investigators on a National Science Foundation grant study that is examining the effectiveness of VDPs & bug bounties.
If youâ€™re running one & would like to have your anonymized data included, email info@Lutasecurity.com with the Subject â€œNSF study dataâ€.

Putting any assumptions about security maturity on the answer to the question

â€œDo you have a Vulnerability Disclosure or bug bounty program?â€

is like a doctor asking you if youâ€™ve ever had a glass of water in your life to assess your current state of health or present hydration

Many will have their anecdotal stories that show Program successes even without prep, but the pattern weâ€™ve observed over decades is that once the enthusiasts & champions leave the org, those formerly â€œhealthyâ€ VDPs & bounty programs inevitably decay & security health with them.

Be suspicious of anyone telling you itâ€™s easy & to just get started to see what kind of bugs you have that Internet hackers can find.
Thatâ€™s YOUR job & if your org doesnâ€™t already have a process to prevent, identify, & fix bugs, donâ€™t think a VDP or Bounty is a replacement for it
